title: 105_s642
content: The "Explosives Protection Act of 1997" prohibits certain activities related to explosive materials. The "Explosives Protection Act of 1997" prohibits the sale, delivery, or transfer of explosive materials to individuals under 21 years of age, those indicted or convicted of a crime punishable by over 1 year of imprisonment, fugitives from justice, unlawful users of controlled substances, and those adjudicated as mentally defective or committed to a mental institution. The individual may be prohibited from possessing explosive materials if they have renounced their citizenship, been discharged from the Armed Forces under dishonorable conditions, or are subject to a court order restraining them from harassing or threatening an intimate partner or child. The individual may be prohibited from possessing explosive materials if they are subject to a court order that includes a finding of being a credible threat to the physical safety of an intimate partner or child, and explicitly prohibits the use of physical force that could cause bodily injury. The amended Section 842 of title 18, United States Code prohibits individuals under 21 years of age, those convicted of a crime punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year, and fugitives from justice from shipping, transporting, possessing, or receiving explosives. The amended Section 842 of title 18, United States Code prohibits individuals under 21 years of age, those convicted of a crime punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year, and fugitives from justice, unlawful users of controlled substances, adjudicated as mentally defective, committed to a mental institution, illegal aliens, dishonorably discharged from the Armed Forces, renounced US citizenship from shipping, transporting, possessing, or receiving explosives. The amended Section 842 of title 18, United States Code prohibits individuals under 21 years of age, those convicted of a crime punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year, and fugitives from justice, unlawful users of controlled substances, adjudicated as mentally defective, committed to a mental institution, illegal aliens, dishonorably discharged from the Armed Forces, renounced US citizenship from shipping, transporting, possessing, or receiving explosives. This includes court orders restraining individuals from harassing, stalking, or threatening an intimate partner or child, with a finding that the person represents a credible threat to their safety. This includes court orders restraining individuals from harassing, stalking, or threatening an intimate partner or child, with a finding that the person represents a credible threat to their safety. Additionally, exceptions and waivers are provided for certain individuals, including aliens and nonimmigrant visa holders. The Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101(a)(26)) outlines exceptions for aliens admitted to the US for specific purposes, such as hunting, military personnel, foreign government officials, and law enforcement officers. Waivers are also available for certain individuals. Any individual admitted to the US under a nonimmigrant visa may receive a waiver from certain subsections if they meet residency requirements and submit a petition approved by the Attorney General. The individual must meet residency requirements and submit a petition approved by the Attorney General, including a written statement from the embassy or consulate authorizing engagement in prohibited activities.
